channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Red vs. Red in Texas, With Republicans Battling One Another After Mask Order
item.description: The virus has heightened long-simmering friction in the largest Republican-led state in the country, with Gov. Greg Abbott under attack from within his own party.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez and J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Ricardo B. Brazziell/Austin American-Statesman, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas gave an update on hospital bed capacity and virus strategy last month in Houston. Texas has become one of the largest coronavirus hot spots in the country.

item.title: Portland Mayor Hit With Tear Gas Deployed by Federal Agents
item.description: Mayor Ted Wheeler denounced federal officers for an “egregious overreaction.” Some protesters mocked him, recalling the city police’s use of tear gas on demonstrators.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker
item.media:description: Mayor Ted Wheeler reacting to tear gas at a protest in Portland, Ore., early Thursday.

item.title: Derek Chauvin Charged With Multiple Tax-Related Felonies in Minnesota
item.description: The former Minneapolis police officer and his wife were charged with filing fraudulent tax returns from 2014 through 2019.
item.dc:creator: Will Wright
item.media:credit: Hennepin County Sheriff, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Derek Chauvin, a former police officer, is accused of killing George Floyd.

item.title: Coronavirus Hospitalizations in the US Near April Peak
item.description: The rising hospitalizations reflect the scale of serious illnesses: Nearly as many people are in hospitals now as there were when New York was at its worst.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Pete Kiehart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency medical workers responded last week to a call for someone thought to have the coronavirus in Durham, N.C.

item.title: 2020 Election Live Updates: Biden Campaign Releases Full Video of Conversation With Obama
item.description: President Trump assailed Representative Liz Cheney, a leading House Republican who has been accused of disloyalty. Michael Bloomberg’s gun control group is putting $15 million toward races in eight states.

item.title: Trump Sends In More Federal Agents
item.description: Chicago’s mayor cautiously agrees to receive help: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Bloomberg's Everytown for Gun Safety Pours $15 Million Into Races in 8 States
item.description: The group, Everytown for Gun Safety, hopes to help Democrats flip three Senate seats, win control of state legislatures and lift Joe Biden to victory in Florida.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Chet Strange for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael R. Bloomberg’s gun control group, Everytown for Gun Safety, has pledged to spend $60 million during the 2020 campaign.

item.title: Remote Learning? No Thanks.
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Popular Chinese-Made Drone Is Found to Have Security Weakness
item.description: Researchers found a potential vulnerability in an app that helps power the drones, highlighting U.S. officials’ concerns that Beijing could get access to information about Americans.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Julian E. Barnes and Aaron Krolik
item.media:description: Researchers found a vulnerability in an android app that controls drones made by China-based Da Jiang Innovations.

item.title: In Picking Up Work Here and There, Many Miss Out on Unemployment Check
item.description: For millions of people, making a living is a cobbled-together proposition. That leaves a hole in the safety net when things turn bad.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: John Tully for The New York Times
item.media:description: Annie Frodeman juggled shifts as an airport ramp agent and registering emergency room patients. Ineligible for state unemployment insurance, she applied for federal benefits, but hasn’t gotten a check.

item.title: A High-Tech Array of Travel Tools: ‘Smart’ Health Cards,Temperature-Reading Glasses and More
item.description: Products that rely on artificial intelligence aim to make travel safer during the pandemic. But hefty prices and privacy concerns are issues.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin

item.title: How Equity Is Lost When Companies Hire Only Workers With Disabilities
item.description: Employment remains an elusive goal for many. A recent hiring strategy may win pats on the back, but advocates fear it may pigeonhole people with disabilities.
item.dc:creator: Wendy Lu

item.title: Trump Defends His Cognitive Testing Results on Fox News. Again.
item.description: The president again tried to defend his own mental fitness for office — and disparage Joe Biden’s — by frequently repeating a memory sequence: “Person. Woman. Man. Camera. TV.”
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Trump repeatedly recited what he said was a sample cognitive testing sequence in an interview on Wednesday.

item.title: House Democrats Considered 10 Impeachment Articles Before Narrowing Their Case Against Trump
item.description: The question of what to include in the case against President Trump is at the heart of a new book by Norm Eisen, a lawyer working with House Democrats in the impeachment effort.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
A Case for the American People (Book)
item.media:description: House Democrats initially drew up 10 articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump last year, according to a new book to be published next week.

item.title: China’s Mars Mission, Tianwen-1, Begins Its Monthslong Journey
item.description: The combined orbiter, lander and rover will reach the red planet in February, if all goes well. NASA plans a Mars launch of its own next week.
item.dc:creator: Michael Roston and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: China’s Long March 5 rocket blasted off from Wenchang Space Launch Center on Thursday, starting the Tianwen-1 mission’s journey to Mars.

item.title: Republicans, Deeply Divided on Virus Aid, Near Agreement on an Opening Offer
item.description: Republicans said they had reached an agreement in principle on their opening bid for coronavirus relief, but they remain divided. They have yet to even begin negotiating with Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane, Nicholas Fandos and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, left, the majority leader, and Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, walking in the Capitol on Tuesday.

item.title: Accuse, Evict, Repeat: Why Punishing China and Russia for Cyberattacks Fails
item.description: So far, there is scant evidence that these punishments have limited the cyberattacks and other bad behavior from America’s two greatest rivals for influence and power around the world.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Mark Mulligan/Houston Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Employees at the Chinese Consulate in Houston burned papers after the United States ordered it closed, prompting firefighters and the police to rush to the area.

item.title: Trump Denies Talking to Ambassador About Moving British Open to His Resort
item.description: Ambassador Robert Wood Johnson IV did not deny the episode, but in a Twitter post he wrote that he did not violate any regulations.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Asked about the report at a coronavirus briefing on Wednesday, President Trump denied speaking with Ambassador Johnson about his Turnberry resort.

item.title: Canada-U.S. Asylum Treaty Is Unconstitutional, Canadian Court Says
item.description: The treaty has long been criticized by human-rights advocates who said it tacitly encouraged asylum-seekers to circumvent Canada’s official land borders.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A Royal Canadian Mounted Police officer warning a family in 2017 that they would be arrested if they tried to cross into Canada from the United States.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: One region in the United States has managed to control the virus.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: 3 Charged in ‘Massacre’ of 3 Friends During Florida Fishing Trip
item.description: The killings last Friday shocked Frostproof, Fla., a city of 3,200 people about 70 miles south of Orlando.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson and Christina Morales

item.title: Miami Mayor Wants Florida to Mask Up, Too
item.description: Mayor Francis Suarez of Miami, a Republican, wants President Trump and Governor Ron DeSantis to enforce a masks-in-public rule.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: House Votes to Remove Confederate Statues From U.S. Capitol
item.description: The bipartisan vote to banish the statues from display was the latest step in a nationwide push to remove historical symbols of racism and oppression from public places.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The statues of John C. Calhoun of South Carolina, left, a former vice president who led the pro-slavery faction in the Senate, and Charles Brantley Aycock, the former governor of North Carolina and an architect of a violent coup d’état led by white supremacists, in the U.S. Capitol.

item.title: AOC Upbraids Republican Ted Yoho After He Denies Vulgarly Insulting Her
item.description: Representative Ted Yoho apologized for the tone of a run-in with Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, but denied calling her a misogynistic pair of expletives. “Not an apology,” she responded.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez voting last month. Ms. Ocasio-Cortez, a favorite of the progressive left and frequent target of Republicans, said Wednesday that she had been the victim of “verbal assault.”

item.title: ‘Nothing About Us Without Us’: 16 Moments in the Fight for Disability Rights
item.description: The disability civil rights movement has many distinct narratives, but the prevailing themes are of community, justice and equity.
item.dc:creator: Julia Carmel
item.media:description: [Image description: People seated in wheelchairs in front of an American flag. The stars on the flag form a symbol of a person in a wheelchair.] Demonstrators outside the Capitol in March 1990.

item.title: Covid-19 Patients No Longer Need Tests to End Isolation
item.description: Under new guidelines from the C.D.C., recovering coronavirus patients should be free to resume normal activity after 10 days, if they have no fever or other symptoms.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coronavirus testing delays of up to two weeks persist in parts of the country.

item.title: Calls for Trump to Invoke Defense Production Act as Coronavirus Surges
item.description: Experts say the law could be more actively used to secure medical supplies, but the Trump administration’s reluctance has left states and medical providers in “chaos.”
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:description: Assembly line workers producing ventilators at a Ford plant in Ypsilanti, Mich., in May.

item.title: Before the A.D.A., There Was Section 504
item.description: In 1977, people with disabilities held sit-ins to demand action on a law that granted accessibility, paving the way for the Americans With Disabilities Act.
item.dc:creator: Julia Carmel

item.title: Congress Sends Landmark Conservation Bill to Trump
item.description: The legislation for the first time guarantees money for land acquisition and preservation, but conservatives denounced it as a federal land grab.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors at Grand Canyon National Park this month.

item.title: Charles Evers, Businessman and Civil Rights Leader, Dies at 97
item.description: Galvanized by the assassination of his brother, Medgar, he helped transform Mississippi politics, running for Congress, becoming a mayor and gaining wide attention.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:description: Charles Evers at his home in Hattiesburg, Miss., in 1998. After the assassination of his brother, Medgar, in 1963, he replaced him as the Mississippi field director of the N.A.A.C.P.

item.title: U.S. Deports Terrorism Convict It Had Sought to Hold Indefinitely
item.description: The Trump administration sent the stateless man who had served his sentence to an undisclosed country rather than defend never-before-used executive authority to keep holding him.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg

item.title: Constance Curry, 86, Ally in Civil Rights Fight and Author, Dies
item.description: She was a bridge between Black activists and white Southerners, worked for Andrew Young and chronicled a Black Mississippi family’s struggle against racism.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:description: Constance Curry at her home in Atlanta in 2017. She spent her entire adult life committed to social justice.

item.title: Can You Become Reinfected With Covid-19? It's Very Unlikely, Experts Say
item.description: Reports of reinfection instead may be cases of drawn-out illness. A decline in antibodies is normal after a few weeks, and people are protected from the coronavirus in other ways.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Megan Kent of Salem, Mass., tested positive for coronavirus in March 30 after feeling sick. She got better, went back to work and then felt sick again in May, testing positive a second time for the virus.

item.title: Painting Bleak Portrait of Urban Crime, Trump Sends More Agents to Chicago and Other Cities
item.description: The announcement came as the president painted a dark vision of crime in cities and attacked local officials who have expressed concerns about intervention by the administration.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:description: President Trump on Wednesday at the White House during an event about violent crime in American cities.

item.title: Its Top Curator Gone, SFMOMA Reviews Its Record on Race
item.description: The senior curator resigned amid anger among staff that boiled over when he used the term “reverse discrimination” — and now the museum is trying to address additional staff complaints.
item.dc:creator: Carol Pogash
item.category: San Francisco Museum of Modern Art
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: SFMOMA is now having a wider discussion of race, and on Tuesday, the board chairman sent an email to staff in which he said the director “is committed to transforming SFMOMA into an anti-racist institution.”

item.title: Biden Could Quickly Reverse Trump’s Military Transgender Ban, Group Says
item.description: An advocacy group says the Pentagon would not need months to study how to allow transgender people to serve, because it had already done so to prepare the Obama policy that was reversed.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Progressive advocacy groups are hoping that a Biden presidency would undo a number of President Trump’s orders.

item.title: Sierra Club Says It Must Confront the Racism of John Muir
item.description: Muir, a monumental figure in American environmentalism and a Sierra Club founder, traded in “deeply harmful racist stereotypes,” the organization said.
item.dc:creator: Lucy Tompkins

item.title: Within Days, Florida Family Loses Two Siblings to Coronavirus
item.description: Byron Francis died suddenly of the coronavirus in June. Eleven days later, his sister Mychaela had died of it, too.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer and Azi Paybarah

item.title: Marciano Foundation Settles Lawsuit Over Layoffs
item.description: Each of the workers who was dismissed amid the labor dispute is expected to receive about 10 weeks of pay, said a lawyer who represented them.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan
item.category: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees
item.media:credit: Emily Berl for The New York Times
item.media:description: As part of the settlement with the Marciano Foundation, District Council 36 dropped a charge of unfair labor practices filed with the labor board, a union official said.

item.title: Study Links Gas Flares to Preterm Births, With Hispanic Women at High Risk
item.description: Expectant mothers who lived near flaring sites had higher odds of giving birth prematurely than those who did not, researchers found. The adverse outcomes fell entirely on Hispanic women.
item.dc:creator: Julia Rosen
item.media:description: A flare in Loving County, Texas. Energy companies flare natural gas when it is too abundant to capture and sell, or when low prices make doing so unprofitable.

item.title: Samantha Diaz, Florida Health Care Worker, Dies at 29
item.description: She left behind three children — two of whom have the novel coronavirus — in the care of her parents. “Our world came crashing down,” her mother said after Ms. Diaz died of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
